column5: Gullrock. Five Lakes Lodge. 15 year annual run with no plans on stopping. This year am doing a 2nd fall trip for the first time.
Fourth for Witch Bay. Missed our trip this year due to some college payment obligations but planning for next year. You won't be disappointed.
Kabeelo. My wife and I went last year. Lots of walleyes, including quite a few between 25" and 27.5". Also some northern up to 40". A first class operation.

We have been going to a camp in the Ignace area that is part of the English River system. The walleye fishing has been good at times, but not huge numbers of fish by any means and really no big fish (over 25"). Would like any input or suggestions of lakes/camps in Ontario for a fall trip with the opportunity for good numbers of walleyes along with the chance for really good size. At this point , we would take large walleye over numbers of fish. Any suggestions are appreciated. Thanks!
You probably should provide some more information, such as where in Ontario you are willing to travel to, if you want to drive, boat or fly-in and if you prefer an outpost camp or a lodge.
We are really open to anywhere in Ontario. We are looking for a drive-in camp where we can bring our own boat. Typically have our own cabin. A boat in camp is also ok. Thanks!

Check out www.birchdalelodge.com on Eagle Lake 807-227-5262 Also take a look at Eagle Eye Guiding on Facebook, Greg guides on Eagle Lake and has been posting pictures of some of the Walleye caught this year.
I love lake of the woods around the morson area. If your wanting just mid- upper 20" walleyes and not just numbers it would be hard to drive by north west part of rainy lake in the fall.
try lac des mille lac, 40 miles east of ignace, in upsala
Witch Bay Camp. Been to others...went to Witch Bay once...will not go anywhere else after experiencing this camp and what it offers. First rate service all the way around.http://www.witchbay.com/
3rd vote for Wicth Bay Camp. Been there 3 times in five years and looking forward to next trip!

Been fishing Ontario for 35+ years and been all over Ontario. Other than doing a private fly in the best walleye fishing I have found is in the Gullrock/Red lake area. Gullrock in the fall is darn good. Wrights camp is a great place to stay. Closer to the fishing than the other camps on the lake. Not much pressure in the fall. Just my opinion.
